urn:contentItem:5X94-J611-JB20-G4P1-00000-00Barry Diller Talks about Netflix, Disney, China and the NBA; Chris Kowalik on Helping Veterans; EU and Britain Reach Draft Brexit Deal; Trump's Meeting with Democrats over Syria; Netflix's Mixed Earnings; Rep. Elijah Cummings Dead at 68; UAW and GM Reach Tentative Deal.2019-10-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:42ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTArt Hogan, Chris Cordaro; Barry Diller, Chris KowalikNEWSFinancial101701cb.231Barry Diller Talks about Netflix, Disney, China and the NBA; Chris Kowalik on Helping Veterans; EU and Britain Reach Draft Brexit Deal; Trump's Meeting with Democrats over Syria; Netflix's Mixed Earnings; Rep. Elijah Cummings Dead at 68; UAW and GM Reach Tentative Deal.Maria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Deirdre Bolton, Griff Jenkins, Grady Trimble, Cheryl Casone

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Two major breaking news stories right now.

Maryland Congressman and House Oversight Committee Chairman Elijah Cummings is dead at the age of 68. Cummings passed away overnight at John Hopkins Hospital from complications from long-standing health challenges.

The other breaking news this morning is a draft deal has been made on Brexit. U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson says he has reached a great new deal with EU negotiators and is urging parliament to approve it this week.

Markets are spiking this morning on this news. We are looking at a triple digit gain for the Dow Industrials this morning, up 114 points on the Dow. S&P futures are up 12 and the Nasdaq futures right now up 38 and a quarter.

We have breaking news as well.

Maryland Congressman and House Oversight Committee Chairman Elijah Cummings has passed away. His office releasing this statement moments ago. At approximately 2:45 a.m. on Thursday, October 17, 2019, Congressman Elijah E. Cummings passed away at Johns Hopkins Hospital due to complications concerning longstanding health challenges. More details will be forthcoming.

Elijah Cummings represented Maryland's seventh congressional district since 1996. He was just 68 year's old.

We're getting this breaking news out of Europe as well, and that is spiking markets this morning. A report says that Britain and the EU have reached a Brexit deal. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson just tweeted this out a moment ago, we've got a great new deal that takes back control. Now parliament should get Brexit done on Saturday so we can move on to other priorities, like the cost of living, the NHS, violent crime and our environment. Get Brexit done. Take back country, wrote Boris Johnson this morning.

Joining the conversation this morning, Fox Business' Dagen McDowell, National Securities Corporation chief market strategist Art Hogan, and Fox Business' Deirdre Bolton.

Great to see everybody this morning.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Great to see you.

ART HOGAN, CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST, NATIONAL SECURITIES CORPORATION: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: What a morning.

Your reaction to the Brexit story?

MCDOWELL: I'll just add, before Art gets in here, that Jean-Claude Juncker, the European Commission president, also has posted something on Twitter this morning saying, where there is a will, there is a deal, and we have one. It's a fair and balanced agreement for the EU and the U.K. and it is a testament to our commitment to find solutions.

So that is very magnanimous.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we heard it from both sides now.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: It looks like Brexit is happening.

HOGAN: Yes, that's a really good deal (ph). We're actually getting confirmation on both sides is something that we definitely needed to hear this morning, but it's also getting one of the -- the biggest market impediments behind us. In large part we're thinking about how slow the global economy has been. Brexit's been part of that. It's been part of that for three years. We kind of take it for granted that at some point in time it was going to get taken care of. This is coming as a bit of a surprise how quickly this is getting accomplished.

MCDOWELL: One thing. The EU, the 27 leaders in the European Union and British prime minister, Johnson, must approve this text at a summit over the next two days in Brussels. Then it goes to Britain's parliament, which has rejected three times a previous deal negotiators by Mr. Johnson's predecessor, Theresa May.

So, again, there is a number of hurdles, but this is certainly good news.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And you see it in the markets.

BARTIROMO: This has got to be good for the banks especially because the banks have headquarters there. They have been sitting on cash, waiting to see what would happen here amid this uncertainty.

HOGAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And the pound is jumping as well, we should point --

BOLTON: Sure.

MCDOWELL: About up 1 percent against the U.S. dollar.

BOLTON: It's also good for the tech community. There's so many tech companies, even American tech companies, that have headquarters in Ireland, or at least significant businesses in Ireland. This was actually really that Irish backstop deal. This is apparently the point of compromise and this was really one of the bigger sticking points. So it seems like both sides have come to some sort of agreement as to how to handle northern Ireland being part of U.K. and southern Ireland being its own country and aligned with the EU -- in the EU.

BARTIROMO: We don't have news on a deal just yet in terms of a trade deal with the U.K. in the EU, but I assume that comes soon, to hear some details there.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: That was what was the sticking point.

HOGAN: Right. Right. And the -- and the Irish backstop is obviously the -- the hardest of the hurdles to get through. There's a reason that London is one of the financial centers of the world, too, when you think about it. Their times zone sits between Asia and the United States. They -- they're extremely important. The Fin (ph) technology, incubator of the world. So a lot of important things that have been dragged down and this has been a very long, drawn out process. So I think any good news on this front is going to help markets though (ph).

BOLTON: Yes. And I think they had that EU summit. They were trying to get this done before that. And then it was the October 31st, you know, sort of appropriately, like, Halloween day was really -- that was the day that it all fell apart no matter what. So I guess both sides have realized, OK, we'll do something. The clock is ticking. We'll sort it out.

BARTIROMO: Well, it's true. I mean people were thinking, how is this possibly going to happen in next two weeks and yet here they have this deal.

BOLTON: All right, fingers crossed.

HOGAN: Right.

BARTIROMO: All right, markets are rallying on this news.

There is other news as well.

President Trump faced off against House lawmakers over Syria yesterday. It was quite a meeting. The president holding a tense bipartisan meeting after the House voting overwhelming to oppose the administration's withdrawal from Syria. The meeting ended with Democrats walking out. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi commented yesterday. But first the president on his decision.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Syria doesn't want Turkey to take its land. I can understand that. But what does that have to do with the United States of America and they're fighting over Syria's land. Are we supposed to fight a NATO member in order that Syria, who is not our friend, keeps their land? I don't think so.

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA): We just came from a most unsatisfactory meeting at the White House. The meeting started by the president saying he never invited any of us there. He asked for the meeting and he just couldn't handle it, so he kind of engaged in a meltdown. And we were trying to get the answer, what is your clear plan for this resolution asked for, for how we fight -- how we fight ISIS. It was very sad. It was very sad.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Vice President Mike Pence and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo are set to arrive in Turkey within the hour. We spoke to him yesterday, of course, when they were about to leave. They will be discussing the situation. And, of course, we know that there's been a tremendous amount of pushback from Republicans, Dagen, on the president's plan to pull out of Syria.

MCDOWELL: A rebuke. A very loud rebuke by Republicans, not just Democrats, in the House of the pullout from northern Syria. It was -- Democrats voted 225 to zero. But Republicans also voted. "The Wall Street Journal" editorial writes about this, Kurds, 354, Trump 60.

They -- but the Republicans who voted two to one in favor of this rebuke, this opposition to the withdrawal from northern Syria, those Republicans, including Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, Whip Steve Scalise and Conference Chair Liz Cheney, just to name a few.

Again, this is a great pushback. And I will just read from another story in "The Wall Street Journal" this morning that this was so sudden and unexpected and, quite frankly, rash to put our allies, the Kurds, in harm's way and to basically cede power to two of our sworn enemies, Russia and Iran. And -- well, three, and Syria, that the U.S. forces have continued moving away from previously occupied Syrian bases and they actually had to call in an Apache helicopter and jet fighters to ward off armed Turkish backed group. Two jet fighters carried out air strikes to destroy an ammunition storage facility, latrines and tents and other parts of the Syria headquarters of the U.S. campaign to destroy the Islamic State. It also, again, gives -- potentially gives rise to the Islamic State, which we had not destroyed but certainly defeated in the short run.

BARTIROMO: And this is really the pushback that I gave Secretary of State Mike Pompeo yesterday --

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: Because right now we're seeing reports that because the Kurds are being overrun by the Turks, they are leaving their positions in front of those jails, which are holding ISIS fighters. And the ISIS fighters are being let out. That was one major issue. The other major issue to point out is the out fields in Syria. And if you're going to open up the oil fields to allow the Iranians to get in there, then they're no longer on their heels, they're going to get revenue to actually continue to support ISIS.

MCDOWELL: And in terms of the argument that this is about bringing our troops home, well, that's not happening. The United States is sending 1,800 troops to -- to repositioning them in -- I think it's 1,800, to Saudi Arabia. So it's very disturbing to not just Democrats. This is a bipartisan, again, rebuke of President Trump's decision.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, I -- you know, I -- the decision, obviously the president has a strategy here, but we haven't lost many people in Syria in five years. I mean one loss is too many, I recognize that, but so far it's really been a support situation that the U.S. has had for the -- for the Kurds, for providing armament, providing, you know, weaponry and being there in terms of an advisory role. So this is -- we'll wait to hear more from the president on this, of course.

Meanwhile, markets are up this morning as -- as earning season rolls on as well. That's another positive for these markets. Dow Industrials at the high of the morning now, up 129 points. Morgan Stanley will be reporting its third quarter numbers in about an hour and a half. We will have those numbers for you. The stock is up going into the print (ph), up 1.5 percent.

Netflix is doing well this morning. It posted mixed results last night with sluggish subscriber growth and yet the stock is up better than 8 percent right now on Netflix as the streaming war is intensifying and people bet that this company is going to keep dominating, Art.

HOGAN: Yes, it's amazing. The international growth continues. And I think the biggest concern was they missed last quarter and they missed significantly. So this was a bit of a miss in terms of where we thought they were going to be in the (INAUDIBLE). We were looking for about 7 million. They came in at 6.8. But all of that came internationally.

But the headwinds that everybody knows about are priced into the stock at this point in time. It's down double digits since the last time they reported. So when you think about the percentage drop that we've seen of this, that has everything to do with who's coming into their marketplace. Disney's coming in. Apple's coming in. they're coming in the same day. NBC's got a streaming product.

BARTIROMO: Don't forget Amazon.

HOGAN: Exactly. So it's going to be a very difficult and complicated space. But Netflix has got a core constituent that probably sticks with them. The problem is, where does the growth come from when there's a lot of other choices?

BOLTON: Well, I think they've even telegraphed, right, that it's not domestic. So I think that's also why the stock didn't move after hours because they haven't said domestic is going to be disappointing --

HOGAN: Right.

BOLTON: But they've more or less telegraphed that in saying, OK, our growth is overseas. If you're with us for the growth in that area, we're in more than 100 companies (ph), we're growing.

MCDOWELL: I don't think that you even have any idea, once the Disney product is available, and I'm not talking about just Disney Plus where you get the Marvel movies and the Star Wars films, but you get Hulu, Disney Plus and ESPN, you know, live sports, at the same price that Netflix costs.

BOLTON: Yes, they package nicely.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That -- that's a value proposition that -- and Disney's got so much money, it is going to be advertising, advertising, advertising.

BARTIROMO: That's true. I have a hard time believing Netflix is going to beat Disney with all of the Disney properties.

BOLTON: Yes, that list came out. It was more than 650 that are available right when Disney Plus launches.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Exactly.

We're going to talk with Barry Dillard coming up in this program and he made his bets in terms of who's doing best. You'll want to hear his thoughts on the streaming wars as well.

Meanwhile, the other breaking news of the morning, of course, is the death of Elijah Cummings.

Fox News' Griff Jenkins is in Washington right now with more on what happened with Congressman Elijah Cummings, who passed away overnight.

Griff, over to you.

GRIFF JENKINS, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning.

It's sad news you're waking up to here on Capitol Hill. You know, Elijah Cummings was a fixture up here. He was the powerful chairman of the House Oversight and Reform Committee and he served as a representative for Maryland's seventh congressional district since 1996. It was a statement from his office that broke the news a few hours ago saying at approximately 2:45 a.m. on Thursday, October 17th, Congressman Cummings passed away at Johns Hopkins due to complications concerning long-standing health challenges. More details will be forthcoming.

And we're going to try and head that way and find out more.

Remember, Cummings had been out of Congress, Maria, for about the last month due to medical procedures. He was born and raised in Baltimore and it was a city he dearly loved. He obtained his bachelor's degree in political science from Howard University, then graduated from the University of Maryland Law School. He was expect to return to his office this week. Obviously will not. It was a career that began in the House of Delegates in Maryland.

Cummings was, of course, a key figure also in the impeachment inquiry and was recently feuding with President Trump over the conditions in Baltimore where this morning Baltimore residents are pouring their hearts out in condolences. The archdiocese of Baltimore among them tweeting that their prayers go out to the family because he generously shared his God-giving talents with the people of that city.

He leaves behind a wife, Maya, and three children. Chairman Cummings was 68 year's old.

Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Griff, thanks very much.

Our condolences to Maya Cummings and the family.

Thank you, Griff Jenkins.

We'll take a break.

When we come back, almost a done deal. The United Autoworkers union reaching a tentative agreement with General Motors. We're going to take you live to Detroit. We've got those details coming up.

And then saved in the nick of time. A police officer being hailed a hero, pulling a driver out of a car as a train barreled toward them. More of this incredible footage when we come right back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

After more than a month on picket lines, striking GM workers may soon be back on the job.

Grady Trimble is live outside GM headquarters, as he has been for weeks, in Detroit with the very latest.

Grady, good morning.

GRADY TRIMBLE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Maria.

Barring any unexpected developments, local union leaders are expected to meet here at General Motors headquarters in just a few hours to vote in favor of this tentative agreement. While the official details are still unknown, we're expected to see wage increases for workers, as well as a signing bonus for workers. Other details we're expecting in this contract once it's released this morning are plans for at least one idle GM plant, that plant is just a few miles from here, it was going to be idled by General Motors at the beginning of next year. Now, we're told, it will remain open with a new product line, an electric pickup truck. Also path for temporary workers to full-time employment and health insurance coverage, which has been important for all of the workers we've talked to, that will remain unchanged.

The picketers, however, remain on the picket line. They haven't gone back to work just yet. They're waiting to see the details of this contract until they decide to go back to work and they say they're going to be looking closely at it before they agree to approve it after their local union leaders do.

I do want to bring up one plant, Maria, that has been very important throughout this election season, the Lordstown, Ohio, plant. GM drew the ire of the president when they announced that they were closing it earlier this year. That plant looks like it will remain closed. However, we're told that General Motors, in a joint venture, will build a separate battery plant in Ohio somewhere. So we'll have to wait on the official details. But at least some jobs could be spared in Ohio because of this tentative agreement.

Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Grady, thank you.

Grady Trimble in Detroit this morning.

We'll take a break. When we come back, futures are jumping this morning after British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit announcement. We've got all the details.

What else is moving markets today? Dow Industrials up 119 points.

Then buyer for Barney's. The struggling luxury retailer ready to sell its assets for a big price tag.

All next. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We have breaking news this morning.

Britain making a deal to pull out of the EU. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson praising the agreement. The announcement sending futures higher this morning, along with strong earnings from Netflix and Bank of America.

Joining us right now is Regent Atlantic Chief Investment Officer Chris Cordaro.

And, Chris, it's good to have you on the program this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

CHRIS CORDARO, CIO, REGENT ATLANTIC: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: You buying this rally? You want to buy into this good news?

CORDARO: Well, I think it is great news that they reached an agreement. I went to sleep last night thinking that it wasn't going to happen, and then this morning it does happen. So that takes one of the pieces of uncertainty out.

But we're not out of the woods economically, you know? I must -- I just see that the past bunch of months we've been in this economic tug of war where we get one or two pieces of good news and then followed by some bad news. And so this is some good news, but I still think it's going to be a long struggle with the economy.

BARTIROMO: Art, what do you think?

HOGAN: Chris, what do you think the biggest -- is it -- is it the U.S.- China trade war that's slowing things down? Is it the uncertainty over that? And does the tone of that feel like it's gotten better this month than it was certainly in the month of May or the month of August?

CORDARO: I think -- I think it's the trade war, the uncertainty over that, and I think you also have the consumer, which could -- which is trouble. You know, you've got a lot of individuals out there thinking that we're going to end up in a recession. And the more people that think we're going to end up in a recession, the more we get there.

And what I see from talking --

BARTIROMO: Yes, but the consumer's been strong. I mean I know the last reading was OK, but the consumer has been the best part of this whole story.

CORDARO: It -- it has, although -- although, you know, sort of retail sales go down a little bit yesterday. And I know, just in talking with my clients, that they're fearful that a recession could be around the corner. That -- that's top of mind for them. And the -- the more that's top of mind and the more it becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy.

MCDOWELL: Yes, but very often the optimism or the feeling among consumers doesn't translate into actual behavior. And a lot of people are thinking that we're going to get kind of a resurgence in the economy or a pickup in growth, particularly in the first quarter of next year because of the dramatic drop in longer term interest rates, which has helped with refinancing. And we've also had gasoline prices are lower right now than they were a year ago.

BARTIROMO: Good point. Yes, that's true.

MCDOWELL: That's puts money in people's pockets.

HOGAN: Have we ever had a recession happen when we had 3.5 percent unemployment? It feels like, you know --

CORDARO: Right.

HOGAN: There's so many things we can be concerned about, but the -- there's always this notion of, can we talk ourselves into a recession? I don't think we can. I think they're -- the Michigan Consumer Confidence number that came out last week shows how consumers actually feel. Yes, there's a lot of things to be concerned about, geopolitical issues. There's all sorts of concerns over, you know, Brexit and the -- and the GM strike and the U.S.-China trade war. But all the -- the tone around all of that seems to be getting better, not worse, and it feels like we're inflecting (ph).

And the data point that I would point to is housing. I think if you look at the housing data that we got yesterday, and over the last three months, that inflected in December has only gotten better, you know, throughout the course of this year.

CORDARO: Yes. The other thing on the positive that you wouldn't -- you wouldn't see a recession, you usually see a recession where there's an asset bubble. And I can't really find an asset bubble. Yes, there's -- the market may be a little richly priced, but it's not a bubble. And housing is not a bubble. And I don't think real estate in general is a bubble, so --

HOGAN: Except for IPOs, right? That --

BOLTON: I was just going to say, in the private market --

HOGAN: Right.

BOLTON: If you talk to Softbank, there's a bubble. If you look at WeWork or Uber.

HOGAN: Right. Yes.

BOLTON: What's the best part of the market in your read (ph) then (ph)?

CORDARO: Well, I think -- I think with what's going on, and you've -- you've just got people exhausted on both sides, I -- I -- I look to retrench back to some more value names. And so, you know, some stocks that I like are Royal Dutch Shell. I -- I think that -- I think that's a really solid name as far as a very high dividend payer, selling at a really good value price. And even a -- even the price of oil is declining, they're one of the lowest cost producers.

MCDOWELL: And then you also have the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates, expected to cut again, even based on what the -- the yield curve is doing with -- cause -- with the reinversion, where the three month's finally lower than the 10-year yield. That's a signal that the market is -- does think that the -- the Fed is going to cut again. And the Fed does seem to be ahead of the curve this time based on --

BARTIROMO: Now, huh?

MCDOWELL: Based on just where say weekly jobless claims are coming in.

HOGAN: One hundred percent. And I think that when you look at what they've had to do to stop into the overnight lending markets too, which is not -- we're not going to call it quantitative easing, but they're certainly showing that they're supportive and want to make sure that there is no friction in the financial system. And I think that that's -- that's probably what they're going to address at the end of this month as well.

CORDARO: It would be -- it would be interesting how they view Brexit because part of what they've been looking at is they've been looking -- they've been looking at the weakness in -- in -- in foreign economies and not wanting that to be contagion to the U.S. So getting ahead of it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but don't forget about earnings. It started off pretty strongly, right? This last week we had some very good numbers in the banking sector.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BOLTON: If it weren't for the financials. Right.

HOGAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: So does that -- I mean I know the expectations are for a negative performance for the third quarter, but, so far, it's only the first week.

CORDARO: Yes, I mean I think in -- in -- I think we'll see low, single digit earnings growth. So it -- it won't -- it won't be terrific, but -- but it will -- but it will be decent.

BARTIROMO: All right, Chris, great to get your insights.

CORDARO: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much, Chris Cordaro there.

Coming up, an amazing save. A Utah cop pulls a driver out of a car stuck on train tracks seconds before the impact of the train.

And then IAC and Expedia's CEO Barry Diller joins me next talking Netflix, big tech, and even the NBA-China controversy, all right here, next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, October 17th.

Your top stories right now just before 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast. We have a lot of breaking news this morning.

A draft deal has been reached on Brexit. U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson says that he has reached a great new deal with EU negotiators and he is urging parliament to approve it this week. EU Commission President Jean- Claude Junker telling member nations to back the deal. Both sides saying they've got a deal.

Futures are showing the markets poised for a higher opening as a result of this. Dow Industrials up in the triple digits, up 113 points. S&P futures up 11.5, and the Nasdaq futures up 33 points right now. Markets finished down slightly yesterday after consumer spending came in lower than expected. It was a fractional move. Dow Industrials down 22, S&P was down 5 and the Nasdaq down 24.

Global markets this morning following a draft deal on Brexit are also higher. European indices higher across the board. FT 100 up 45, CAC quarante up 14 and the DAX index in Germany up 74.

In Asia overnight, here's the situation where it was mixed. Hang Seng did well, up two-thirds of 1 percent. The others down fractionally.

The streaming war continues. Netflix getting a boost from overseas subscribers, but falling a bit short on overall growth expectations. The streaming giant downplaying the threat of other media powerhouses, entering the streaming field. The stock is up this morning almost 8 percent on Netflix.

Coming up later this morning, Morgan Stanley will be out with earnings. We'll have those numbers for you and you take a look at any impact. The stock right now going into the quarterly report, up one and two-thirds percent.

A dramatic rescue caught on tape. See the moment a trooper risks his life to save a driver from an oncoming train. Amazing pictures there.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning.

But our top story this half an hour, Netflix posting mixed results last night with sluggish subscriber growth. The stock is up 7.5 percent. IAC and Expedia Chairman Barry Diller last year predicted Netflix would win the coming streaming wars. His -- he has not changed his mind. Now, new services are seemingly coming on the market every day. That's just one of the headlines from my exclusive interview with Diller.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Is everybody catching up to Netflix?

BARRY DILLER, CHAIRMAN IAC AND EXPEDIA: No.

BARTIROMO: Really?

DILLER: That does not mean that, for instance, what Disney is doing is not sound for Disney. And they're doing it. And I have great admiration for Bob Iger because he's the -- he -- he made a determination that he had to have direct engagement with the consumer. And the only way to do that is through streaming. So it's not like he put his little toe in the water. He put both feet, both legs, and a whole body in the water and he's going for this completely. And Disney has such appealing content that I think they'll do well. Will they ever get to Netflix's size? I can't imagine it. It seems incomprehensible to me that that will happen.

BARTIROMO: Even though they've got Marvel, Lucas, Pixar, Fox?

DILLER: That's OK. That's fine. Yes, so what. I mean, in other words, I'm not saying they're not going to get subscribers. But they're not going to get to the -- to the level of Netflix worldwide. Netflix has been in this - - look, it is, when you think of it, it's such a radical miracle that six years ago they invested in what was thought to be an obscene amount of money in a single program called "House of Cards," OK. Six years ago they put down $150 million for -- which no one at the time could even conceive of. But their guts and really the extraordinary thing -- now, here's this company, not very well capitalized, that starts in the streaming business and then makes such big bets that they change the entire entertainment business and change the 100 year's old hegemony of these major, you know, entertainment companies. So that they've done this and then they said, right away, we're going worldwide. So they planted their little flags in every place in the world years ago.

BARTIROMO: So do they have to spend $13 billion a year to keep up?

DILLER: They have to spend it for as -- for a while, for sure. It's all overspending. All of the money that's going into this is deficit money. I mean meaning, in other words, you're not going to get a return on these dollars. You're not playing for the short gain. So the thing is, can you get enough subscribers over the next couple of years to be able to then actually cut back on your program expenditures, probably raise some prices too, and make this come out in terms of the economics? I think that's a neat trick, but I think it's doable.

The thing is that the prices that have -- this competition has made a -- this is a land rush to get programming. The results of it is, it used to be that you'd produce an hour of television, let's say on "Law and Order" or whatever, normal hour television program, for maybe a $1.5 million, $2 million. They're spending $8 million, $10 million, $12 million, $13 million, $15 million an hour for programs, now that's kind of nuts. And it'll go on until this arm's race stabilizes.

BARTIROMO: So you think that Netflix's success was first built on "House of Cards"? That show was incredible.

DILLER: There's no question.

BARTIROMO: I agree. I didn't realize it was that show that really propelled it.

DILLER: It was. It was -- it --

BARTIROMO: I loved that show.

DILLER: Well, enough people took -- it was that it created something that people had never seen. Here was a high-priced, really well-produced, extremely expensively produced television series that was sold directly to consumers. So when they saw that and already Netflix had been, you know, had some subscribers. When they saw it they said, oh, my God, this is a better way to consume stuff.

BARTIROMO: Do you want to acquire Groupon?

DILLER: No.

BARTIROMO: Do you want to acquire Yelp?

DILLER: No.

BARTIROMO: Why not?

DILLER: I don't know.

Well, look, if Yelp -- you know, I've admired what they've done, but the issue in situations like that really does come down to, where does it fit, does it fit really, you know, next to our home service business because they -- they do some home services and we actually -- they -- I think they're making some -- or they've had some deal for our (INAUDIBLE) home service to use Yelp to, you know, for their home service department (ph).

BARTIROMO: I can see the synergy (ph).

DILLER: So there are synergies there.

Then it comes down to price, and that has not made sense.

BARTIROMO: Are you surprised at what's taken place, Barry. I mean you and I watched the Internet boom and the Internet bust, and now you've got some real survivors, like an Amazon. Are you surprised at what Amazon looks like today?

DILLER: No, I'm not really surprised because early on Jeff Bezos' concentration -- phonetical concentration on serving the consumer when no one else really, in his area or arena was doing so --

BARTIROMO: You're right (ph).

DILLER: With such consistency. And because of that plus just a genius of a kind of ambition that is really wildly rare, Amazon, there's nothing -- no, Amazon -- we actually tried to buy their bonds when they got into trouble and if it weren't for Vivendi, which owned a piece of our company at the time, if we would have done so. I've been an admirer of Amazon for 20 years.

BARTIROMO: But stay on this tech space for a second because you look at a Google, you look at a FaceBook. These companies are more powerful today than they ever have been.

DILLER: Yes.

BARTIROMO: That's why you see Washington now saying, we might want to break them up.

What kind of regulations changes are you expecting?

DILLER: Well, I don't believe -- I don't believe breaking them up make any sense. What I do think is they have to have -- they -- there has to be sensible regulation. When these companies get to the size that they are, then, in fact, like any monopoly, they must have sensible regulation. So for Google, we spend -- at Expedia, we spend $3.5 billion -- well, we probably spend $2.7 -- we spend about $3.5 billion in marketing. Ad (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: Yes, they want your advertising but they also want your customers.

DILLER: We spend multiple billions of dollars. And that's fine. We spend the money. They give us customers.

What we don't like is them then competing with us in our own business. So we think that's kind of wrong and we've been saying it for many years and we think that eventually this will, like other things that get to excessive, you know, get excessive, this will get taken care of by regulation. Sensible regulation is mandatory. When you get these businesses that are that -- that have that level of -- they're truly monopolies.

BARTIROMO: Google has 90 percent market share in search.

DILLER: I have always -- I've always said that if, you know, it's -- if you're Google, it's kind of wise, since everybody is a -- is a surf on your land, that it's good to treat the surfs kind of nicely because otherwise the surfs rise up and come after you.

BARTIROMO: Do you have a thought on China and what's going on right now between the U.S. and China? What's your reaction to all of this, the fact that the NBA is over here defending what -- what the general manager of Houston Rockets said and then China's bullying them and they rollover. And then Marriott rolls over.

DILLER: You could kind of say it was inevitable. I mean, you know, China has been growing and China has more people than any place else. It also has a regime that can basically say it here and it comes out there. They don't have to depend upon staying in office, so to speak. And they're very competitive. And so we are seeing the results of them getting very strong and wanting to get stronger and they will keep doing it and push back against that is good and healthy for the U.S., I think, and for everybody else because that kind of -- that kind of economic potential imbalance and China absolutely does believe in one man standing. In other words, you know, we've done business in China and, in the end, we basically had to sell out because, in fact, in almost every industry, there's only one survives.

So that's a very competitive place to play. And you're going to see all these tensions and all these reactions where China can say, if the NBA does something they don't like or a player does somebody or somebody says something here they don't like --

BARTIROMO: Then, get out.

DILLER: They can simply by decreeing it. There's no -- there's no real rule of law. So --

BARTIROMO: No. By the way --

DILLER: They do what they can get away with.

BARTIROMO: Alibaba doesn't have to follow the same rules that Amazon has to follow in terms of accounting, even though Alibaba trades in the U.S.

DILLER: For sure.

BARTIROMO: Barry, it's great to have you here. Thanks so much.

DILLER: A pleasure.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: All right, that was Barry Diller.

Breaking news, Vice President Mike Pence landing moments ago in Ankara, Turkey. He will soon be joined by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. They are set to meet with Turkish President Erdogan to discuss the potential for a ceasefire to Turkey's recent incursion on Syrian border towns. We will take you there as news develops, and, of course, we will probably get news this morning on this conversation.

We'll slip in a short break. When we come back, hailing a hero. A police officer pulling a driver out of a car as a train barreled toward it. More of the incredible footage coming up.

Then earnings season in full swing. We are watching for Morgan Stanley this morning. All the numbers as soon as they hit the tape and the impact.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome Back.

We have breaking news this morning.

U.K. and EU negotiators have reached a Brexit deal.

Cheryl Casone with more headlines now.

Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Yes, that certainly powered up the markets this morning, Maria, and good morning to you.

That draft agreement announced just hours before it goes before a European Union summit that start in Brussels today. That's a two-day summit. Now, this deal must still be proved by Britain's parliament, which, remember, rejected three earlier proposals from former Prime Minister Theresa May. Now current Prime Minister Boris Johnson says that vote will likely be held this Saturday.

The British pound did rally on that news. And, again, futures moved here in this country on this breaking news.

Now, the main sticking point has been how to keep the border open between northern Ireland, which is part of the U.K., and Ireland, which is part of the EU.

Well, Barney's New York has reached a deal to sell its assets to Authentic Brands and B. Riley Financial. The price estimated to be around $270 million in cash. This is according to a court filing. This calls for all remaining Barney's stores to close. Barney's filed for bankruptcy protection back in August citing rent hikes as a factor. New York City landmark, folks.

And then staying with New York City. We are a step closer here to shuttering the infamous Rikers Island jail by 2026. The council committee voted to green light Mayor de Blasio plan to build four new jails around the city, every burrow but Staten Island. The full city council is going to vote on that measure later today, Maria.

And finally this, a dramatic rescue. A highway patrol officer in Utah risked his life to pull a man off of the train tracks just moments before that train barreled through.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We've got to get out of here. We've got a train coming. We've got a train coming. We've got a train coming. We've got a train coming. We have a (INAUDIBLE) train coming.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Close call. Dash cam video showed the officer dragging the unconscious driver away from those tracks seconds before the train did slam into that car. Talking later, the officer, Maria, said, quote, I was just doing my job.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

CASONE: It is amazing what some of our police officers do across this country that don't get credit for things like that.

BARTIROMO: You're right. A big shout-out to them, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes. You bet.

BARTIROMO: On the jail story, positive op-ed in "The Journal" about Rikers Island, saying that Rikers Island is a mess, it needs to be closed down. But a completely different take from "The New York Post" today.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Yes.

BARTIROMO: "The Post" headlines, closing Rikers will make New York City less safe and put dangerous gang members and murder suspects on the streets. The city council must say no today. This is what we've been talking about now for literally a year. It feels like crime is picking up in New York already and three out of those four jails are going to be in Brooklyn and it's not going to have the capacity that Rikers Island has even right now. And that's down from the peak, right, Dagen?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: This is a big story even nationwide because you have a large part of the far left pushing for the decriminalization, well, of crime, even simple assaults and petty larceny. Arrests for low level crimes have been plummeting around the United States in major cities.

And one thing I'll point to, there was a story in "The Wall Street Journal" recently about New York City. And once charges for trespassing, resisting arrest and marijuana offenses started falling in 2011 after the stop and frisk tactics were ended under Mayor Bloomberg. But I will quote, under Bill de Blasio, the mayor, and Manhattan District Attorney Cy Vance, the decline extended to other crimes, like simple assault, petty larceny, turnstile jumping, they are not arresting people for shoplifting. They are not arresting people for punching people in the head.

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable.

MCDOWELL: That it -- turnstile jumping, that's -- that's something else. But, again, when you make it open season on merchants throughout your entire city, where people can walk into a Dick's Sporting Goods --

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: If you will, or a CVS, take whatever they want, security tries to stop them, the security guards put their hands on them and they start screaming bloody murder and get your hands off me, the cops don't show up. It turns into anarchy and it will be the death of these major cities.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Because people will not stay here.

BARTIROMO: Yes, make sure everybody looks at what's happening in Los Angeles with the -- with the homelessness problem there, and San Francisco with the poop on the street and the needles on the street, because it's coming to New York.

Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is backing this coalition call No New Jails New York City. She doesn't want any jails.

MCDOWELL: And it hurts the working-class New Yorker.

BARTIROMO: (INAUDIBLE).

MCDOWELL: It hurts the working-class resident of all of these cities because the rich can pick up and leave.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: They can go overseas. They can go to a no-tax state, like Texas.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: But it's the ranking and file people who have to take the subways and walk and basically fend for their lives. When there's a mugging outside of this building --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: There's a rape down the street.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Stop it.

BARTIROMO: We're going to keep warning everybody about this, as we have been doing for a year. This is a huge story.

We're going to take a break.

When we come back, veterans helping veterans. We're talking to one Marine helping others prepare for the future. Wait till you see this story. That's next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Well, this morning, we are saluting a veteran success story. One Marine helping others prepare for the future. ProFeds pairs federal employees with financial professionals to insure they have enough security to retire and education around it.

Joining us right now is the owner of ProFeds, Chris Kowalik, who, for five years, served as an Arabic linguist and signals intelligence analyst in the U.S. Marine Corps.

Chris, it's great to have you. Thanks so much for joining us.

CHRIS KOWALIK, FOUNDER, PROFEDS AND RETIRED MARINE: Wonderful. Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: And thank you for your service in our country.

KOWALIK: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Tell us the background of Profeds. How did you start this?

KOWALIK: You know, when I left the Marine Corps, I knew that I wanted to have a passion for continuing to serve, perhaps in a different way than I originally set out for. And so when I started ProFeds, I wanted the ability to be able to inspire federal workers to properly prepare for the days when they no longer have to work. And so I'm very lucky to be able to do that today.

BARTIROMO: In terms of the transition from military life into business life, and to starting ProFeds, how tough is that?

KOWALIK: It was tough because there's so much in the Marine Corps that I absolutely adored and I wasn't sure that I was going to find that same passion out in the private sector. And so I'm really grateful to be able to do that and apply so many of the skills that I had when I was serving our country in the military to be able to continue to serve the federal workforce today.

MCDOWELL: These are financial planning tools. I was surprised that these weren't available to the people in the military, both serving currently and who have served in the past, or federal workers in general.

KOWALIK: Right.

MCDOWELL: That -- I'm surprised there was that need there?

KOWALIK: It was a big surprise for me as well. And I knew that I could provide the training, but that was only the first step. Then what? Once everyone gets the information, what do they do with it? And so I knew if I was going to be able to have the transportation that I was seeking for all of these people to feel like they had control over their own retirement, that I had to be able to pair them with a person that could help them take the next step and fill in the blanks.

BOLTON: What's the biggest challenge for them? Because they're coming from a very structured environment to one that's not as structured.

KOWALIK: Right. So --

BARTIROMO: And what is their education level on this stuff?

KOWALIK: Most of the time when folks come to our training, they've never experienced any training like this before. So they're right at the end of their career and all of them say something of the nature, I wish I would have done this 10 or 20 years ago and taken those steps to put time on their side. And, luckily for us, we get to -- to help them at least at the end. We'd prefer to help them a little bit earlier in their career. But to let them get this training and walk out the door and feel like there's a path forward that I can take is really rewarding.

BARTIROMO: Great stuff.

MCDOWELL: Great.

BARTIROMO: It must be very satisfying as well.

KOWALIK: Very much so.

BARTIROMO: Chris, it's great to have you. Thank you so much.

KOWALIK: Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: Chris Kowalik joining us there.

Still ahead, Brexit breakthrough. More on Boris Johnson's great new deal next hour right here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:608J-1HP1-DYDW-705D-00000-00Basecamp's protest of Apple's policies is already benefiting other developers2020-07-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:41ZLexisNexisBasecamp's protest of Apple's policies is already benefiting other developersNew Delhi, 2020-07-03 15:48:50

July 03 -- A weird thing about running a tech company is that if you are very successful, at some point you will also be operating a vast quasi-legal system. Up to a certain point, one of your users complaining that they got locked out of their account is just a customer service problem. But after some threshold - after you've reached a billion people, certainly, but also well before then - the same complaint can look strangely like a human rights issue. Do you have the right to speak? Do you have the right to conduct business? And if you lose that right, to whom do you appeal?


That's one reason I suspect Basecamp's public protest of Apple and its App Store policies has gotten so much traction. Basecamp, you will remember, is a mid-sized 16-year-old company that makes project management software, and a week ago it introduced a new email service called Hey. Because email is the kind of service you expect to be accessible on all your devices, Basecamp made six native clients for Hey, including one for Apple's iOS. I installed it on my phone and used it without any issue during the time I was reviewing Hey.
But then Basecamp submitted its first bug fix release for Hey, and Apple rejected it. The issue: Hey did not let users sign up for the product within the app. Apple presented this purely as a customer experience issue - account creation is a necessary part of an email app - but it was also a revenue issue. Apple keeps 30 percent of revenue from signups like these, and Basecamp did not want to give it to them. Eventually Apple said it had been a mistake to let Hey into the App Store to begin with.
If we lived in a world with more than two mobile phone operating systems, it seems unlikely that Apple would be able to take 30 percent of an email app's revenue just for hosting it in an app store. Instead the fees might resemble those in the more competitive payments industry, which hover in the low single-digit percentages. But more than 1.5 billion iOS devices are in use, and many of the customers who would potentially pay for Hey at $99 a year are users of those devices and expect to find Hey there. Amid a flurry of interest lately in Apple's anticompetitive behavior from regulators here and in the European Union, Apple's obstinance in the Hey case drew outsized attention. What once might have been dismissed as a lone, cranky developer seemed symbolic of a larger injustice.
 
It started to look, in other words, like something closer to a human rights issue.
The Basecamp developers are - and I say this with fondness - loudmouths, and they have seemed to relish in highlighting the various logical gaps and inconsistencies in the App Store's policies and their enforcement. Look close enough at any system of law or content moderation and it can start to feel arbitrary, but Apple's has proven to be particularly vulnerable to criticisms. What Apple has prevented Hey from doing, for example, it has allowed the much larger Netflix to do, because Netflix has been designated a "Reader" app, exempting it from offering sign-up within the app. Maybe there's a good, principled reason for holding email apps to one standard and video streaming apps to another. Or maybe Apple is just playing favorites.
In any case, users of the App Store don't get to vote, and neither does Hey.
What Hey could do, though, was embrace Apple's pretzel logic and concoct the strangest app imaginable, a dadaist take on email whose sole real purpose was to highlight the absurdity of software development in the modern era. And that's just what it did. Here's Nilay Patel writing Monday in The Verge:
Basecamp isn't done with the fight. The company has submitted a new version of Hey that meets the strict letter of Apple's rules but clearly defies their spirit: the company will now offer iOS users a free temporary Hey email account with a randomized address, just so the app is functional when it is first opened. These burner accounts will expire after 14 days. Hey is also now able to work with enterprise customers, as Apple initially took issue with the app's consumer focus.
Hey has not adopted Apple's own in-app payment system or allowed users to sign up for its full, paid service through the iOS app. Instead, users will still need to subscribe by going directly to Hey's website.
Surprisingly, it worked - at least for now. Hey is in the App Store as negotiations continue. And whether out of fear of antitrust regulation or a desire not to see this week's Worldwide Developer Conference overshadowed by a developer dispute, the historically obstinate Apple has even shown sides of yielding. Nick Statt had the surprising news at The Verge:
Apple today announced two major changes to how it handles App Store disputes with third-party developers. The first is that Apple will now allow developers to appeal a specific violation of an App Store guideline, and that there will also be a separate process for challenging the guideline itself. Additionally, Apple says it will no longer delay app updates intended to fix bugs and other core functions over App Store disputes.
"Additionally, two changes are coming to the app review process and will be implemented this summer. First, developers will not only be able to appeal decisions about whether an app violates a given guideline of the App Store Review Guidelines, but will also have a mechanism to challenge the guideline itself," reads a press release from Apple published this afternoon. "Second, for apps that are already on the App Store, bug fixes will no longer be delayed over guideline violations except for those related to legal issues. Developers will instead be able to address the issue in their next submission."
Buried hundreds of words into a long press release about improvements to the developer experience, "a mechanism to challenge the guideline" doesn't exactly leap off the page. At the moment, no other details are available. But these changes suggest that Apple is taking an important question - who has the right to conduct business? - more seriously than it has before, and might begin to answer it in a more rigorous and principled way.
At the moment, this "mechanism" sounds less ambitious than what Facebook is attempting with its Oversight Board, an independent group that later this year will begin hearing appeals from people who believe their posts have been removed in error. Facebook has spent more than two years developing the board, funded it with $130 million, and it still isn't operating quite yet.
 
But the basic idea is the same. If our entire working and personal lives are to be mediated by the policies of four or five for-profit corporations, those policies will have to shift from a mindset of customer service to one of justice. I find it heartening that Apple is moving down this path, even if took Basecamp dragging them there.
The RatioToday in news that could affect public perception of the big tech platforms.
Trending up: Twitter is giving US employees Election Day off from now on. Employees around the world will get paid time off to vote in national elections. (Barbara Ortutay / Associated Press)
Trending up: Facebook is adding spending trackers to every US Senate and House race through the Facebook Ad Library. The information will allow the public to track how much each candidate is spending on political ads on the platform. (Salvador Rodriguez / CNBC)
Trending up: Amazon launched a $2 billion fund to advance technologies that will cut down greenhouse gases. The fund will help Amazon reach its goal of becoming carbon neutral by 2040. (Justine Calma / The Verge)
Trending down: But Amazon also said its carbon footprint rose 15 percent last year. The company revealed that activities tied to its businesses emitted 51.17 million metric tons of carbon dioxide in 2019, the equivalent of 13 coal burning power plants running for a year. (Joseph Pisani / Associated Press)
Governing⭐ Twitter restricted a tweet from President Trump where he promised to use "serious force" if Washington, DC ever tried to create an autonomous zone like Seattle's Capitol Hill Occupied Protest area. The company said the tweet violated its policy against abusive behavior. Adi Robertson at The Verge has the story:
Restricted tweets can't be liked or replied to, although they can be retweeted with a comment. Despite this, Trump's huge social media following almost guarantees any tweet will be widely seen on Twitter. So the decision is largely symbolic, but it helps Twitter stake out a position of acknowledging and acting on Trump's problematic social media posts - in contrast with Facebook, which has kept a largely hands-off approach but did remove a Trump ad for using Nazi imagery last week. A Facebook post with Trump's "serious force" message has so far not been labeled or removed.
Facebook suffered a setback in a key challenge to its advertising model, as Germany's highest civil court said that it has "no doubt" the social network misuses its dominant market position. The court ruled that Facebook must comply with a strict order curbing how it tracks users' browsing and smartphone apps. Facebook is appealing the decision. (Karin Matussek / Bloomberg)
Weeks after content moderators reached a $52 million settlement with Facebook over trauma they suffered working for the company, many are being told that they must view some of the most disturbing content on the internet for an extra 48 minutes per day. (Sam Biddle / The Intercept)
 
Nine months after Facebook vowed to investigate abusive posts by anti-vaxxers, none of the users involved have been penalized. Anti-vaxxers have posted violent, horrific comments and death threats to vaccine advocates on the platform. (Elizabeth Cohen / CNN)
The police chief who helped create the "Facebook Unit" in Menlo Park abruptly stepped down on Friday, citing a loss of community trust. Earlier this month, local residents protested the police unit, and demanded Facebook cease funding the Menlo Park Police Department. (Sarah Emerson / OneZero)
More than 70 employees at Mark Zuckerberg's philanthropy are calling for significant internal change at the organization to combat systemic racism. Employees at the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative are asking management to commit to 12 changes that will make the philanthropy more inclusive. (Theodore Schleifer / Recode)
Facebook is suing a developer who is allegedly behind a data scraping campaign that took personal information, including login credentials, from thousands of people. Facebook has increasingly turned to lawsuits to stop data abuses on its platform in recent years. (Alfred Ng / CNET)
Twitter and Apple spoke out against Trump's suspension of a variety of guest worker visas. The new restrictions would fall particularly hard on H-1B visas, which are often used by tech companies to hire foreign workers without engaging a traditional immigration process. (Russell Brandom / The Verge)
Google also released a statement condemning the new restrictions, saying: "Immigrants have not only fueled technological breakthroughs and created new businesses and jobs but have also enriched American life." (Russell Brandom / The Verge)
A group of black YouTube creators filed a lawsuit regarding alleged racial discrimination in the YouTube algorithm. They say the platform has been systematically removing their content without explanation. (Reed Albergotti / The Washington Post)
The FBI used Instagram, an Etsy review, and LinkedIn to identify a protestor accused of setting two police cars on fire during recent protests in Philadelphia. The case shows how police have been able to use social media and other publicly-available online records to identify protesters from just a few scraps of initial information. (James Vincent / The Verge)
As local governments ease shelter-in-place restrictions related to the coronavirus pandemic, they're relying on contact tracing apps to help stop the spread of the disease. But the apps are far from ready for a major rollout, as this latest piece on the subject documents. (Rolfe Winkler and Patience Haggin / The Wall Street Journal)
China is cracking down on live-streaming services for "vulgar content" amid their explosion in popularity due to the coronavirus pandemic. The move is hitting big Chinese tech companies like Tencent and ByteDance. (Wayne Ma / The Information)
EU officials admitted the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) has been difficult to implement and enforce. Regulators have struggled with a lack of clarity around how the rules apply to fields like artificial intelligence, blockchain and the internet of things, and the burden has fallen most heavily on small businesses. (Javier Espinoza / Financial Times)
Industry⭐ More than 70 people in the gaming industry, most of them women, have come forward with allegations of gender-based discrimination, harassment and sexual assault since Friday. They have shared their stories on Twitter, YouTube, and Twitch. Here's Taylor Lorenz and Kellen Browning at The New York Times:
The outpouring of stories from competitive gamers and streamers, who broadcast their gameplay on platforms like Twitch for money, led to the resignation of the C.E.O. of a prominent talent management company for streamers and a moment of reflection for an industry that has often contended with sexism, bullying and allegations of abuse.
Already, the response has been a far cry from Gamergate in 2014, when women faced threats of death and sexual assault for critiquing the industry's male-dominated, sexist culture. Now, some are optimistic that real change could come.
Over the weekend, a former Mixer employee shared a blog describing his experiences with racism while working at Microsoft's streaming platform. The post included allegations that upper level management refused to act when a racist analogy was used during a meeting. (Ian Walker / Kotaku)
As a streaming platform, Mixer was ultimately a failure. But it kicked off a talent war between the big streaming platforms that will likely continue even after Mixer no longer exists. (Andrew Webster / The Verge)
 
Microsoft's surprise closure of Mixer comes with a plan to port its creators over to Facebook Gaming. But it's difficult to find many Mixer streamers who are willing to move to Facebook instead of the much more popular, Amazon-owned Twitch. (Tom Warren / The Verge)
Pinterest sent an email to staff saying it will add a person of color to its board and will start evaluating managers based on diversity hiring. The news comes in response to employee concerns about racial disparities after two black former workers on the policy team said they faced discrimination there. (Sarah Frier / Bloomberg)
Facebook promoted tips to help users spot fake news. When scientists tested the effectiveness of the company's advice, the lessons appear to work. Encouraging news. (Kaveh Waddell / Consumer Reports)
Oculus is ending sales of its low-end Oculus Go virtual reality headset to focus on Oculus Quest. The company will maintain Oculus Go firmware through 2022 and accept new apps through December 2020, but it will stop selling Go hardware after the current stock runs out. (Adi Robertson / The Verge)
Accessibility advocates criticized Twitter for the lack of captions in the company's brand-new audio tweet feature. The company doesn't have a team dedicated to accessibility, instead relying on employees who volunteer their time above and beyond their usual duties. It's not a good look. (Kim Lyons / The Verge)
Social media influencers are actively participating in the online conversation about racial justice following the police killing of George Floyd and the resurgence of the Black Lives Matter movement. In the past, many say they lost followers for speaking out about politics. (Rachel E. Greenspan and Kat Tenbarge / Insider)
Things to doStuff to occupy you online during the quarantine.
Play a new game on Houseparty. It's called Word Racers and it looks fun!
Look at this botched art restoration. The destruction of our cultural heritage is a tragedy but also I can't stop laughing!
Subscribe to Bnet. Brian Feldman is an excellent internet culture writer who recently left New York magazine. His newsletter, Bnet, is a reliably sharp and entertaining guide to trending memes that you may or may not have already encountered. Half the posts are free; I'm a happy paying subscriber.
Watch a possum play tic-tac-toe. His name is Pablo and he's better than you might guess.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5K07-K2J1-DYX0-43NV-00000-00Basic income: Silicon Valley resolves to disrupt poverty2016-06-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:41ZLexisNexisNEWSANALYSISBasic income: Silicon Valley resolves to disrupt povertyCaroline Craig

An interesting development has arisen: Universal basic income has become the darling of Silicon Valley. But before you get up and dance to "Money for Nothing," brush up on what Greek mythology has to say about Trojans who wheel gift horses into the city.

Technologists -- from Tim O'Reilly to venture capitalist Albert Wenger to authors and entrepreneurs such as Peter Diamandis and Martin Ford -- suddenly seem eager for government to hand out cash to us ordinary folks. Some, such as Sam Altman, are even putting their money where their mouth is. The president of startup incubator Y Combinator is funding a five-year study in Oakland on the effects of giving people enough money to live on, no strings attached.

[ Simon Phipps tells it like it is: Why software patents are evil. | Cut to the key news in technology trends and IT breakthroughs with the InfoWorld Daily newsletter, our summary of the top tech happenings. ]

What gives? When Silicon Valley leaders speak out, "it is usually to disparage the homeless, celebrate colonialism, or complain about the hapless city regulators who are out to strangle the fragile artisans who gave us Uber and Airbnb," as The Guardian wrote.

Basic income bromance

In the '60s and '70s, when this country was caught up in a War on Poverty, basic income was an idea that had the support of people ranging from economist and libertarian hero Milton Friedman to Martin Luther King Jr. to Richard Nixon. Now the idea is undergoing a revival -- and not only in Finland, the Netherlands, and Canada, which are all implementing experiments with basic income.

Silicon Valley's embrace of the concept seems at first blush to be fueled by a belief that technology -- specifically breakthroughs in automation, AI, and machine learning -- could soon make people as obsolete as workhorses. In such a future, basic income will be necessary to stave off a Luddite uprising.

"Don't destroy the robots," says Professor Jeffrey D. Sachs of Columbia University. "But recognize that not everybody would be better off as a result of market forces. With redistribution everybody could be made better off."

Of course, not all experts are convinced of humanity's impending redundancy. According to the New York Times, for every analysis forecasting that half of all jobs in the United States will be replaced by new technology there are others finding no such evidence.

What can't be denied is the widening gap between rich and poor in the United States. Tech's supporters of basic income often point to this growing gap as proof that accelerating technology creates inequality. According to this theory, The Guardian says, capitalism is meritocratic and technology enriches "those exceptional few who are smart enough to perform tasks that are too complex or creative to automate, while impoverishing the rest." 

But if technology really is to blame for this growing gap, why has wage growth stagnated for pretty much all workers -- Wall Street excluded? People in IT earn about as much today in inflation-adjusted dollars as they did in the late 1990s.

Good cop or bad cop?

Inequality isn't the inevitable by-product of technology, The Guardian argues. If it were, other industrialized countries would have levels of inequality comparable to the United States -- which they don't. Instead, Silicon Valley's embrace of basic income is "the Trojan horse that would allow tech companies to position themselves as progressive, even caring -- the good cop to Wall Street's bad cop" when what's probably needed is a transformation of the tax code.

Don't fool yourself: Tech investors don't expect to pony up and fund these basic income payouts. Heck, many are pioneers of tax avoidance schemes to avoid paying any taxes at all.

Nor do they propose putting an end to their gold rush on personal data. We are all currently giving away our data for free to tech giants. Telecom data alone is currently worth $24 billion per year, on its way to $79 billion in 2020, according to estimates by 451 Research.

What if instead of asking the needy to foot the bill, through the elimination of government programs like public housing, food stamps, and Medicaid -- as Libertarians and conservatives propose -- the basic income was structured like a dividend from tech companies for our "natural resources," like Alaska does with its oil taxes and profits?

Spread the wealth

If Silicon Valley really wants to take steps toward the introduction of basic income, "why not make us, the users, the owners of our own data?" proposes Evgeny Morozov, author of "The Net Delusion: The Dark Side of Internet Freedom." "Think of a mechanism whereby ... data that now accrues almost exclusively to the big tech firms, would compensate citizens for their data with some kind of basic income, that might be either direct (cash) or indirect (free services such as transportation)."

This will never happen, Morozov says, "because data is the very asset that makes Silicon Valley impossible to disrupt -- and it knows it .... Somehow our tech elites want us to believe that governments will scrape enough cash together to make [basic incomes] happen. Who will pay for it, though? Clearly, it won't be the radical moguls of Silicon Valley: They prefer to park their cash offshore."

The tech industry has fed on a steady stream of public goods ever since the U.S. military funded Silicon Valley into existence, The Guardian says. "Those goods might be government research, mined for profitable inventions, or the contents of your Gmail inbox and Facebook feed, mined for advertising revenue. What matters is they're free, and they're free because we give them away. If the robots ever arrive, their arrival will be bankrolled by our taxes, our attention, our data."

Ben Tarnoff calls a basic income policy under these circumstances "the crumbs left by the bully who steals your sandwich." It seems there really is no free lunch.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5SCX-5DS1-DYTM-94WC-00000-00BAT Takes a Swing at Insurance: China's tech giants are transforming the insurance market.(Technology: China Platforms)2018-05-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:42ZLexisNexisPg. 50BAT Takes a Swing at Insurance: China's tech giants are transforming the insurance market.(Technology: China Platforms)Smith, Kate

Baidu, Alibaba and Tencent--the tech behemoths known by the acronym BAT--are fixtures in the everyday lives of Chinese citizens. Originally a search engine, an e-commerce platform and a social networking site, respectively, the big three have expanded far beyond their core businesses. They offer cloud computing, digital payments and, increasingly, insurance options.

Over the past seven years, the big three have aggressively targeted the financial services sector. And with a combined market cap of more than $1 trillion, according to Yahoo Finance, they have become a force to reckon with... or partner with.

To understand the impact the BATs have on the Chinese insurance sector, Best's Review turned to David Wu, partner and Hong Kong insurance sector leader for Deloitte China, and Joanna Wong, a consulting partner at Deloitte China.

Baidu, Alibaba and Tencent all have made moves into the insurance space. What's driving their interest in insurance?

Wu: Since 2011, the BATs in China have aggressively expanded the reach, scale and accessibility of their digital platforms into the financial services space. The speed and scale of investment has also made China one of the fastest-growing insurtech leaders in the world.

The move made by the BATs into the insurance space recognizes their desire to leverage one of the most important assets for an insurance company--a rich and diverse but relevant range of data.

According to Deloitte China's research, there are about 1 billion Chinese netizens currently using mobile devices to browse the internet. They spend around 106 hours online every month versus 54 hours in the U.S. Meanwhile, 52% of the time spent online are spent on apps developed by the BATs, which have secured their titles as the three biggest internet giants in China through their unique capabilities and their abilities (including communication, entertainment, shopping, mobility and navigation, as well as information) to influence the daily life of Chinese citizens.

These interactions provide a vast amount of data that the BATs could effectively leverage to run a profitable insurance business.

At the same time, regulatory developments and market trends have supported the rapid proliferation of insurance technology disruptions across the nation.

How are the BAT companies transforming insurance in China?

Wong: The BATs are transforming insurance in China in three major ways: Disrupt distribution and servicing, foster product innovation to align to "real" customer needs, shorten the product development cycle. Online insurers can reach out to customers in remote locations where they do not have a physical presence. This has given rise to the growth of new insurance products enabled by the digital economy. The rise of innovative products that address new insurance needs are also arising. In addition, internet giants accelerate the time to market by scaling up the product development process. For example, an online insurance JV [joint venture] invested in by one of these giants can launch a new insurance product in five to six weeks as opposed the typical timeline of six months.

Which of these tech giants is pursuing insurance most aggressively?

Wu: These tech giants have all obtained regulatory approval to either set up their own insurance company or form insurance JVs with local and/or foreign partners. Baidu formed a JV with Allianz and Hillhouse Capital to form BaiAn Insurance. Alibaba formed a life insurance JV with local technology companies and with another foreign insurer to form a P&C JV, in addition to launching an insurance cloud service with another local partner. Meanwhile Tencent was permitted to set up its own online insurance company in October 2017, one month after its online P&C insurance JV partnered with Alibaba and another leading Chinese insurance group had gone public in Hong Kong.

The rapid development of financial technology and growing demand for protection in China fuels more interest in the insurance segment. We believe that these big tech companies will continue to seek opportunities brought by the increasing demand for insurtech, particularly internet-based insurance. Meanwhile, internet companies which aim to hold core assets--customer resources--are not going to just stay as distributors. As such, we expect these players to continue making bolder moves in the near future to tap into the remaining white space in the market.

Tencent could be the most aggressive out of the three tech giants in our view simply because it has been allowed to set up its wholly owned online insurance company. It is also the founding partner of another online insurance JV with two other local partners. It is important to note that Tencent currently owns leading internet and communication platforms in China. It has become a vital part of China's mobile internet industry with a combined MALI [monthly active user] of approximately 938 million in March 2017, all of which strategically support the company to acquire new insurance customers via its vast customer base.
